Problem:
Consider a feedback control system where the state vector \\( x(t) \\) is governed by \\(\\dot{x} = A x + B u\\), with A being the system matrix and B the input matrix. The input \\( u \\) is a function of time and defined by an integral transformation \\( u(t) = \\int_0^t K(s) x(s) ds \\), where K is a kernel matrix function.

Can we definitively ascertain what changes were made to the kernel matrix function \\( K(s) \\), based only on the observed final state \\( x(T) \\), knowing that an intervention occurred at time \\( t_1 \\)?
Explanation: Determining the specific alterations made to \\( K(s) \\) or pinpointing when these changes occurred during the interval [0, T] based solely on \\( x(T) \\) is infeasible. Multiple configurations of \\( K(s) \\) and its intervention with \\( L(s) \\) can lead to the same final state, obscuring the exact nature of the interventions.
